{{rel-top|pronunciation notes}}
The word ''the'' is commonly pronounced {{IPAchar|/√∞iÀê/}} whenever it is pronounced as a distinct word, e.g.:
* When it is used for emphasis ({{l|en||This is where ''the'' hospital for open-heart surgery is}}).
* When the speaker pauses between ''the'' and the next word ({{m|en||the ‚Ä¶ sovereignty}}).
* In many but not all dialects, when the next word begins with a vowel sound ({{m|en||the onion}}) (compare with {{l|en|a}} vs. {{l|en|an}}).
The word is generally pronounced indistinctly as {{IPAchar|/√∞…ô/}} or merely {{IPAchar|/√∞/}} in other situations, such as when attached to a word beginning with a consonant sound.
{{rel-bottom}}
{{rel-top|"the" vs. "ye"}}
The [[eye dialect|typographical pronunciation]] {{IPAchar|/jiÀê/}} (''"'''[[ye#Etymology_2|Ye]]''' Old..."'') is a deliberately archaic [[retronym]] from {{m|en|ye}}, which is a variant spelling of [[√æe]], from Old English [[√æe#Old English|√æƒì]] pronounced '''''thƒì''''', {{IPAchar|/Œ∏eÀê/|/√∞eÀê/}}  (using [[y]] in place of the [[thorn]] ([[√æ]]). It is not actually a separate pronunciation in Middle English. The actual [[morpheme]] {{IPAchar|/jiÀê/}} in Middle English represents [[»ùe-]], a variant spelling of the prefix [[y-]] attached to [[verb]]s and used to denote a verbal [[past participle]].
{{rel-bottom}}

===Etymology 1===
{{root|en|ine-pro|*s√≥}}From {{inh|en|enm|√æe}}, from {{inh|en|ang|√æƒì||the, that|pos=[[demonstrative pronoun]]|g=m}}, a late variant of {{m|ang|sƒì}}, the ''s-'' (which occurred in the masculine and feminine nominative singular only) having been replaced by the ''√æ-'' from the oblique stem.
{{rel-top|replaced words, cognates}}
Originally neutral nominative, in Middle English it superseded all previous Old English nominative forms ({{m|ang|sƒì|g=m}}, {{m|ang|sƒìo|g=f}}, {{m|ang|√æ√¶t|g=n}}, {{m|ang|√æƒÅ|g=p}}); {{m|ang|sƒì}} is from {{inh|en|gmw-pro|*siz}}, from {{inh|en|gem-pro|*sa}}, ultimately from {{inh|en|ine-pro|*s√≥}}.

Cognate with {{cog|stq|die|t=the}}, {{cog|fy|de|t=the}}, {{cog|nl|de|t=the}}, {{cog|nds-de|de|t=the}}, {{cog|de|der|t=the}}, {{cog|da|de|t=the}}, {{cog|sv|de|t=the}}, {{cog|is|s√°|t=that}} within Germanic and with {{cog|sa|s√°|t=the, that}}, {{cog|grc|·ΩÅ|t=the}}, {{cog|txb|se|t=this}} among other Indo-European languages.<ref>{{R:ine:LIPP|volume=2|pages=732-733}}</ref>
{{rel-bottom}}

====Article====
{{head|en|article}}

# {{n-g|Used before a noun phrase, including a simple noun}}
## {{non-gloss definition|The [[definite]] grammatical [[article]] that implies necessarily that the noun phrase it immediately precedes is definitely identifiable}}
### {{n-g|because it has already been [[mention]]ed, is to be completely [[specify|specified]] in the same sentence, or very shortly thereafter.}} {{defdate|from 10th c.}}
###: ''I‚Äôm reading '''the''' book Mary reviewed.'' (Compare ''I‚Äôm reading '''a''' book Mary reviewed.'')
###: ''You live on Main Street, don't you? You know, you should tell the mayor '''the''' street needs cleaning.''
###: '''''The''' men and women watched '''the''' man give '''the''' birdseed to '''the''' bird.''
###: '''''The''' street that runs all the way through my hometown.''
###* {{quote-web|1=en|year=2016|url=https://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/lets-learn-english-lesson-5-where-are-you/3168971.html|site=VOA Learning English|passage=I sleep in '''the''' bedroom!|accessdate=12 December 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930001420/https://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/lets-learn-english-lesson-5-where-are-you/3168971.html|archivedate=30 September 2017}}
### {{n-g|because it is presumed to be definitely known in context or from shared knowledge}}
#### {{non-gloss definition|Used before a noun designating something considered to be [[unique]], or of which there is only one at a time.}} {{defdate|from 10th c.}}
####: ''No one knows how many galaxies there are in '''the''' universe.''
####: ''God save '''the''' Queen!''
####* {{RQ:King James Version|Revelation|1|8|column=2|passage=I am Alpha and Omega, '''the''' beginning and '''the''' ending, saith '''the''' Lord, which is, and which was, and which is to come, '''the''' Almighty.}}
#### {{non-gloss definition|Used to indicate a certain example of (a noun) which is usually of most concern or most common or familiar.}} {{defdate|from 12th c.}}
####: ''No one in '''the''' whole country had seen it before.''
####: ''I don't think I'll get to it until '''the''' morning.''
####: ''Take me to '''the''' airport/station/hospital/office/park/match/meeting.''
#### {{non-gloss definition|Used before a body part, a family member, a pet (especially of someone previously mentioned), as an alternative to a [[possessive pronoun]].}} {{defdate|from 12th c.}}
####: ''A stone hit him on '''the''' head.'' (= ‚ÄúA stone hit him on his head.‚Äù)
####: ''How's '''the''' wife?'' (= "How is your wife?")
#### {{lb|en|colloquial}} {{n-g|Precedes a familiar nickname or other term of address.}}
####:{{usex|en|How's '''the''' Sal today?|footer="How are you, Sal?"}}
#### {{n-g|Used in many idiomatic expressions and proverbs to refer to common objects, roles, or situations connected with something definite, as by analogy}}
####: ''square '''the''' circle; feel '''the''' pinch; beat around '''the''' bush; throw '''the''' baby out with '''the''' bathwater''
## {{non-gloss definition|When stressed, indicates that it describes something which is considered to be best or exclusively worthy of attention.}} {{defdate|from 18th c.}}
##: ''That is'' <u>'''the'''</u> ''hospital to go to for heart surgery.''
##* {{RQ:Doyle Land of Mist|passage="Good Heavens, man! Why, he is '''''the''''' authority. If you want pure laboratory experiments those are the books."}}
##* {{quote-journal|en|date=May 27, 2012| author=Nathan Rabin| title=TV: Review: THE SIMPSONS (CLASSIC): ‚ÄúNew Kid On The Block‚Äù (season 4, episode 8; originally aired 11/12/1992)| work=The Onion AV Club| url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/new-kid-on-the-block,75341/| passage=‚ÄúNew Kid On The Block‚Äù doubles as a terrific showcase for the Sea Captain who, in the grand tradition of Simpsons supporting characters, quickly goes from being a stereotype to an archetype, from being a crusty sea-captain character to '''''the''''' crusty sea-captain character.}}
## {{non-gloss definition|Used before a noun phrase beginning with [[superlative]] or comparative adjective or an [[ordinal number]],  indicating that the noun refers to a single item.}}
##: ''That was '''the''' juiciest apple pie ever.''
##: ''May '''the''' better man win.''
## {{non-gloss definition|Introducing a singular term to be taken [[generically]]: preceding a name of something standing for a whole class.}} {{defdate|from 9th c.}}
##* {{RQ:Mandela Long Walk to Freedom|year=2010|page=536|passage=Stern and God-fearing, '''the''' Afrikaner takes his religion seriously.}}
##: '''''The''' downy woodpecker can be found in the same environments as '''the''' hairy woodpecker.''
## {{n-g|Used with the plural of a surname to indicate the entire family.}}
##: '''''The''' Bushes have held political office for several decades and '''the''' Kennedys longer.''
# {{n-g|Used with an adjective}}
## {{non-gloss definition|Added to a superlative or an ordinal number to make it into a substantive.}} {{defdate|from 9th c.}}
##: ''That apple pie was '''the''' best.''
## {{non-gloss definition|Used before an adjective, indicating all things (especially persons) described by that adjective.}} {{defdate|from 9th c.}}
##: ''Feed '''the''' hungry, clothe '''the''' naked, comfort '''the''' afflicted, and afflict '''the''' comfortable.''
##: ''One doesn't choose the color of one's chess pieces, '''the''' white are assigned to the player who moves first.''
## {{non-gloss definition|Used before an [[demonym]] to refer to people of a given [[country]] collectively.}}
##: '''the''' [[Chinese]]
##: '''the''' [[Irish]]

=====Usage notes=====
{{box-top|Usage notes (with proper nouns)}}
The word ''the'' precedes [[proper noun]]s in a number of cases, although most proper nouns use no article. There are always exceptions. See also [[Appendix:English proper nouns]] for more information.
; Countries
As a general rule, country names are not preceded by ''the''. There are a few exceptions, most of which are [[pluralise]]d:
* [[the Netherlands]] (or [[The Netherlands]])
* [[Bahamas|the Bahamas]] (or [[The Bahamas]])
* [[Maldives|the Maldives]] (or [[The Maldives]])
* [[Seychelles|the Seychelles]] (or [[The Seychelles]]; also used without the article)
* [[Philippines|the Philippines]]
* the [[Solomon Islands]], the [[Faroe Islands]], etc
* [[Gambia|the Gambia]] (or [[The Gambia]])
* {{q|dated|proscribed}} [[Sudan|the Sudan]] (or [[Sudan|The Sudan]])
* {{q|dated|proscribed}} [[Ukraine|the Ukraine]] (or [[Ukraine|The Ukraine]]; article dropped since 1991)
* {{q|obsolete}} [[Yemen|the Yemen]] (or [[Yemen|The Yemen]])
* {{q|obsolete}} [[Lebanon|the Lebanon]] (or [[Lebanon|The Lebanon]])
Names of countries containing specifications like '''kingdom''', '''republic''' etc are used with ''the'':
* [[United States|the United States of America]]
* [[United Kingdom|the United Kingdom]]
* [[United Arab Emirates|the United Arab Emirates]]
* [[Czech Republic|the Czech Republic]]
* [[Swiss Confederation|the Swiss Confederation]]
* [[Kingdom of Denmark|the Kingdom of Denmark]]
* [[Republic of Austria|the Republic of Austria]]
* [[Sultanate of Oman|the Sultanate of Oman]]
* [[European Union|the European Union]]
; Place names
Some place names use a definite article:
* All [[ocean]]s (the Atlantic Ocean, the Pacific Ocean)
* All [[sea]]s (the Red Sea, the Bering Sea, the Caribbean Sea), and [[strait]]s (the Strait of Magellan, the Bering Strait, the Bosphorus) <!--and some bays with e.g. (the Bay of Biscay)-->
* All [[river]]s (the Amazon, the Nile, the Mississippi, the Seine, the Yangtze), [[canal]]s (the Panama Canal, the Suez Canal) and [[delta]]s (the Nile Delta, the Orinoco Delta, the Colorado River Delta)
* All [[art gallery|art galleries]] (the Tate, the Louvre, The Smithsonian American Art Museum), all [[museum]]s with the word ''museum'' in the name (the Museum of Natural History, the British Museum)
* Most English-language [[newspaper]]s (The New York Times, The Guardian, The Chronicle, The Wall Street Journal)
* All North American [[railroad]]s, even when not referred to by their full names or only by nicknames (the Pennsylvania Railroad, the Reading (Reading Railroad), the Frisco (St. Louis‚ÄìSan Francisco Railway))
* Some towns (the Bronx, The Hague, The Valley, The Farrington, The Quarter, The Plains, The Dalles, The Villages, The Woodlands, The Pas, the Vatican, The Hyde, the West End, the East End, or the City of ...)
; Bands
Musical bands with a plural name are generally used with '''the''':
* {{w|The Beatles}}
* {{w|The Rolling Stones}}
; Universities
University names beginning with the word "University", and some other university names, are used with '''the''':
* the University of North Carolina
* the Ohio State University
{{box-bottom}}
{{rel-top|Usage notes (with adjectives)}}
When used before an adjective which is not followed by a noun, it may refer to a group of people for which the adjective is appropriate:
* the Scottish = Scots
* the rich = rich people {{qualifier|considered as a group}}
{{rel-bottom}}

===Etymology 2===
From {{inh|en|enm|the}}, {{m|enm|thy}}, {{m|enm|thi}}, from {{inh|en|ang|√æe|√æƒìÃÜ}}, probably a neuter instrumental form ("by that, thereby")‚Äîalongside the more common {{m|ang|√æ»≥}} and {{m|ang|√æon}}‚Äîof the demonstrative pronoun {{m|ang|sƒì}} ("that"). Compare {{cog|nl|des te|des ''te''}} ("the, the more"), {{cog|de|desto|des''to''}} ("the, all the more"), {{cog|no|fordi|for''di''}} and {{cog|no|av di|av di}} ("because"), {{cog|is|√æv√≠||the; because}}, {{cog|fo|t√≠}}, {{cog|sv|ty}}.

====Adverb====
{{en-adv|-}}

# {{non-gloss definition|1=With a [[comparative]] or with {{m|en|more}} and a verb phrase, establishes a correlation with one or more other such comparatives.}}
#: '''''The''' hotter(,) '''the''' better.'' {{gloss|comma usually omitted in such very short expressions}}
#: '''''The''' more I think about it, '''the''' weaker it looks.''
#: '''''The''' more money donated, '''the''' more books purchased, and '''the''' more happy children.''
#: ''It looks weaker and weaker, '''the''' more I think about it.''
# {{non-gloss definition|1=With a [[comparative]], and often with {{m|en|for it}}, indicates a result more like said comparative. This can be negated with {{m|en|none}}.}}
#: {{ux|en|It was a difficult time, but I‚Äôm '''the''' wiser for it.}}
#: {{ux|en|It was a difficult time, and I‚Äôm {none - not any} '''the''' wiser for it.}}
#: {{ux|en|I'm much '''the''' wiser for having had a difficult time like that.}}
# {{lb|en|with a superlative adjective}} Beyond all others.
#: {{ux|en|We went '''the''' furthest under her leadership.}}
#: {{ux|en|They trusted him '''the''' most.}}

=====Usage notes=====
This is called the "comparative correlative", but it is also known as the "correlative construction", the "conditional comparative", or the "the...the construction".

* {{l|en|nevertheless}}
* {{l|en|nonetheless}}
